title: Assignment 4
text:
Difference between a weak and a strong entity set:

A strong entity set can be identified uniquely by its own attributes, such as an Employee with an Employee ID.
A weak entity set on the other hand, cannot be identified by its own attributes alone and depends on a strong entity (also known as the owner entity) for identification. An example could be a Dependent entity that relies on the Employee entity for its identification (e.g., an employee’s dependent might be identified by the Employee ID and Dependent’s name).

title: Assignment 4
text:
Question 2
Design an E-R diagram for keeping track of the scoring statistics of your favorite sports team. You should store the matches played, the scores in each match, the players in each match, and individual player scoring statistics for each match. Summary statistics should be modeled as derived attributes with an explanation as to how they are computed.

Draw the E-R diagram using draw.io.
Expand to all teams in the league (Hint: add team entity)

title: Assignment 4
text:
Question 3
SQL exercise:

Write an SQL query using the university schema to find the ID of each student who has never taken a course at the university. Do this using no subqueries and no set operations (use an outer join).



Consider the following database, write a query to find the ID of each employee with no manager. Note that an employee may simply have no manager listed or may have a null manager(use natural left outer join).

SELECT e.ID
FROM employee e
OUTER JOIN manages m ON e.ID = m.ID
WHERE m.manager_id IS NULL;

title: Assignment 6
text:
Question 1

Using JSON YouTube: YouTube uses JSON to deliver video metadata, comments, and user interactions through its API. The JSON structure is hierarchical and includes nested fields for video IDs, thumbnails, and statistics such as views and likes. YouTube’s backend likely uses BigQuery and other Google Cloud services to store and manage data. The API fetches this data in JSON format, commonly consumed by frontend JavaScript frameworks.
Using XML W3Schools: W3Schools offers XML data examples, including a sample file that provides information on books. The XML structure uses descriptive tags such as , , and . The data can be accessed using XML parsers in JavaScript or server-side languages. Technologies like DOM and XSLT are used to query or transform the XML structure for web display.



Question 2



SELECT student.ID
FROM student
LEFT JOIN advisor ON student.ID = advisor.s_ID
WHERE advisor.i_ID IS NULL;



SELECT I.ID, I.name
FROM instructor I
WHERE NOT EXISTS (
  SELECT *
  FROM course C
  WHERE C.dept_name = I.dept_name
    AND NOT EXISTS (
      SELECT *
      FROM teaches T
      WHERE T.ID = I.ID AND T.course_id = C.course_id
    )
)
ORDER BY I.name;

title: Assignment 3
text:
Write SQL codes to get a list of:

Students IDs (hint: from the takes relation)



Instructors



Departments





Write in SQL codes to do following queries:

Find the ID and name of each student who has taken at least one Comp. Sci. course; make sure there are no duplicate names in the result.



Add grades to the list



Find the ID and name of each student who has not taken any course offered before 2017.



For each department, find the maximum salary of instructors in that department. You may assume that every department has at least one instructor.



Find the lowest, across all departments, of the per-department maximum salary computed by the preceding query.



Add names to the list





Find instructor (with name and ID) who has never given an A grade in any course she or he has taught. (Instructors who have never taught a course trivially satisfy this condition.)

title: Assignment 1
text:
Name and describe three applications you have used that employed a database system to store and access persistent data (e.g., airlines, online trade, banking, university system).



How it Uses Databases: Stores customer data, transactions, and account details.
Reasoning: Ensures secure, fast, and reliable access to banking information.





How it Uses Databases: Manages product listings, customer orders, and payments.
Reasoning: Uses a relational database to store structured data and provide recommendations.





How it Uses Databases: Stores student records, enrollments, and grades.
Reasoning: Ensures students and faculty have real-time access to course materials and academic records.





Propose three applications in domain projects (e.g., criminology, economics, brain science, etc.). Be sure to include: 1.Purpose 2.Functions 3.Simple interface design



Purpose: Measures and tracks social well-being indicators like mental health, employment, and community engagement.
Functions:

Collects survey responses on life satisfaction, stress levels, and social interactions.
Tracks changes in employment, education, and local crime rates.
Provides visual reports and insights for policymakers and community leaders.

Simple Interface Design: A dashboard displays key indicators like mental health scores, employment trends, and community engagement in charts and graphs. Users can fill out surveys to update data, and policymakers can generate reports with visual insights. The interface includes a homepage overview, survey page, and a report export option.





Purpose: Analyzes public sentiment on social issues by gathering data from social media and news sources.
Functions:

Collects and categorizes posts on topics like inequality, human rights, and policy changes.
Uses sentiment analysis to determine whether opinions are positive, negative, or neutral.
Generates reports on trending social issues over time.

Simple Interface Design: Users enter keywords to analyze public sentiment from news and social media, displayed through a word cloud, sentiment pie chart, and regional heatmap. A live feed shows relevant posts, and a report generation page allows data exports. The interface is search-focused with real-time insights.





Purpose: Tracks data on economic and social mobility to understand inequality trends in different regions.
Functions:

Stores data on income, education, and employment trends across communities.
Provides comparison charts on social mobility rates based on location, gender, and ethnicity.
Recommends policies and resources to improve access to opportunities.

Simple Interface Design: An interactive heat map and dashboard display income trends, education levels, and employment data by region. Users can compare multiple areas, view bar charts, and access policy recommendations. The interface supports searching, visual comparisons, and report downloads.




If data can be retrieved efficiently and effectively, why is data mining needed?
Data mining is essential because it allows us to extract meaningful insights from large datasets beyond just retrieving stored data. Below are key reasons why data mining is needed:




Databases can retrieve data efficiently, but they don’t automatically find patterns or trends.





Data mining helps predict future trends based on historical data.





Businesses use data mining to make data-driven decisions rather than relying on intuition.





Big data is too large and complex for traditional database queries alone. Data mining helps extract valuable insights from massive datasets.





Companies use data mining to gain a competitive edge by identifying market trends, customer preferences, and business risks.





Describe at least three tables that might be used to store information in a social network/social media system such as Twitter or Reddit.
A social media platform like Twitter or Reddit would require multiple tables for structured data management. Below are three essential tables:



Stores information about users.



Column Name
Description




User ID
Unique identifier for each user


Username
Display name of the user


Email
Contact email


Password
Encrypted password


Date Joined
Date when the user registered








Stores tweets or Reddit posts.



Column Name
Description




Post ID
Unique identifier for each post


User ID
ID of the user who posted


Post Content
Text or media content


Created At
Timestamp of post creation


Likes Count
Number of likes


Comments Count
Number of comments








Stores relationships between users.



Column Name
Description




Follower ID
ID of the user who follows


Followed ID
ID of the user being followed


Date Followed
Timestamp of when the follow occurred

title: Assignment 2
section: Question 2: Schema Diagram for Bank Database
text:
Question 2: Schema Diagram for Bank Database
A bank database schema includes the following entities:

BRANCH Table



Column Name
Description




branch_name
Name of the branch


branch_city
Location of branch


assets
Total branch assets





ACCOUNT Table



Column Name
Description




branch_name
Associated branch (🔗 FK → Branch)


account_number
Unique account ID


balance
Account balance





LOAN Table



Column Name
Description




loan_number
Unique loan ID


branch_name
Issuing branch (🔗 FK → Branch)


amount
Loan amount





DEPOSITOR Table



Column Name
Description




ID
Customer ID (🔗 FK → Customer)


account_number
Linked account number (🔗 FK → Account)





BORROWER Table



Column Name
Description




ID
Customer ID (🔗 FK → Customer)


loan_number
Linked loan number (🔗 FK → Loan)





CUSTOMER Table



Column Name
Description




ID
Unique customer ID


cst_name
Customer’s name


cst_street
Street address


cst_city
City of residence





Relationships

One Branch → Many Accounts (branch_name as FK in Account)

One Branch → Many Loans (branch_name as FK in Loan)

One Customer → Many Accounts (via Depositor table)

One Account → Many Customers (Joint accounts, via Depositor)

One Customer → Many Loans (via Borrower table)

One Loan → Many Customers (Co-borrowers, via Borrower)

title: Assignment 2
section: Question 3: Primary and Foreign Keys for the Bank Database
text:
Question 3: Primary and Foreign Keys for the Bank Database

Primary Keys

Branch: branch_name
Account: account_number
Loan: loan_number
Depositor: (ID, account_number)
Borrower: (ID, loan_number)
Customer: ID



Foreign Keys

Account: branch_name
Loan: branch_name
Depositor: ID, account_number
Borrower: ID, loan_number

title: Assignment 5
text:
Question 1: E-R Diagram as a Graph
An E-R (Entity-Relationship) diagram can be viewed as a graph, where entities are nodes and relationships are edges. Understanding its structure helps ensure database integrity and effective design.


a) The graph is disconnected
A disconnected graph means that some parts of the schema are isolated and do not connect to others. In terms of an enterprise schema, this implies that certain entities or relationships are not integrated with the rest of the database system.
Example: Imagine we have a Doctor entity and a Patient entity, but no relationship (like Treats) connecting them. These two entities are disconnected in the E-R diagram.
Implications: - Indicates missing relationships or a design flaw. - Can result in incomplete or difficult-to-query data. - Hurts the ability to enforce referential integrity.


b) The graph has a cycle
A cycle in an E-R diagram means that starting from one entity, you can follow a path of relationships and return to the same entity.
Example: Doctor → Patient → Test → Doctor
This forms a loop (cycle) in the schema.
Implications: - Not inherently wrong – cycles often represent real-world interconnectedness. - Can complicate queries, especially recursive ones. - May require careful normalization or handling to avoid data anomalies.


Question 3: Why Do We Have Weak Entity Sets?
While it’s possible to convert weak entity sets to strong ones by adding attributes, we still use weak entity sets in practice due to design clarity and efficiency.
Reasons We Use Weak Entity Sets:

A weak entity cannot be uniquely identified by its own attributes.
It depends on a related strong entity for uniqueness.

Why Not Always Use Strong Entities?

Making weak entities strong can require adding redundant or artificial keys, which is not always natural.
Weak entities simplify data modeling for real-world hierarchical relationships.
Helps maintain referential integrity and logical clarity in the schema.



Question 4


a: SQL Queries
Schema:
employee(ID, name, street, city)
works(ID, company_id, salary)
company(company_id, name, city)
manages(employee_id, manager_id)

Find ID and name of employees who live in the same city as the location of their company:

SELECT e.ID, e.name
FROM employee AS e, works AS w, company AS c
WHERE e.ID = w.ID AND w.company_id = c.company_id AND e.city = c.city;

Find ID and name of employees who live on the same street and in the same city as their manager:

SELECT e.ID, e.name
FROM employee AS e, manages AS m, employee AS mngr
WHERE e.ID = m.employee_id AND m.manager_id = mngr.ID
AND e.city = mngr.city AND e.street = mngr.street;

Find ID and name of employees who earn more than the average salary of all employees in their company:

SELECT e.ID, e.name
FROM employee AS e, works AS w
WHERE e.ID = w.ID AND w.salary > ( SELECT AVG(w2.salary)
FROM works AS w2
WHERE w2.company_id = w.company_id


b: What’s wrong with this SQL query?
SELECT name, title
FROM instructor NATURAL JOIN teaches NATURAL JOIN section NATURAL JOIN course
WHERE semester = ‘Spring’ AND year = 2017;
Problem: This query uses NATURAL JOIN, which joins tables based on all columns with the same name. This can cause unintended matches, especially if tables have generic column names like ID or course_id.
Fix: Use explicit JOINs to clearly specify matching fields.
Corrected Query:
SELECT i.name, c.title
FROM instructor AS i
JOIN teaches AS t ON i.ID = t.ID
JOIN section AS s ON t.course_id = s.course_id
AND t.sec_id = s.sec_id
AND t.semester = s.semester
AND t.year = s.year JOIN course AS c ON s.course_id = c.course_id
WHERE s.semester = ‘Spring’ AND s.year = 2017;

title: Hi, I am Eman Ajmal
text:
I’m a social data analyst passionate about turning real-world problems into actionable insights.
I care deeply about development, equity, and evidence-based reform, and I’m driven by the belief that small interventions, rooted in data can spark long-term impact.
Currently pursuing my Master’s at UT Dallas, I focus on the intersection of data, people, and policy, and aim to build systems that inform, include, and improve.



“Data is more than numbers — it’s people, stories, and change waiting to happen.”



Connect with me
